p: After treatment with thyme oil, the total inhibition of biofilm development was observed for three strains ( C. tropicalis fo/BM/01, C. pelliculosa LOCK 0007, and C. albicans cl/MP/01) on all of the materials tested ( Figure 1). Additionally, C. albicans ATCC 10231 and C. boidinii fo/MP/01 on the surface of glass and PP, and also C. lusitaniae LOCK 0004 and C. krusei fo/BM/02 on glass, did not grow in a biofilm structure. Furthermore, in the presence of thyme oil 58.3% isolates showed a statistically significant decrease in cells number in biofilm on the surface of glass (by 24.9–66.1%), 68.8% on PET (by 16.0–69.5%), and 50% on PP (by 20.7–71.0%). Only two yeast C. colliculosa fo/KO/02 and C. parapsilosis fo/82/3 were insensitive to thyme oil in the concentrations used, which resulted in biofilm formation on the materials under study ( Figure 1).
